repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
When a plugin registers a TermRequest handler there is currently no way for the handler to know where the terminal's cursor position was when the sequence was received. This is often useful information, e.g. for OSC 133 sequences which are used to annotate shell prompts.

Modify the event data for the TermRequest autocommand to be a table instead of just a string. The "payload" field of the table contains the sequence string and the "row" and "col" fields contain the cursor position when the sequence was received.

To maintain consistency between TermRequest and TermResponse (and to future proof the latter), TermResponse's event data is also updated to be a table with a "payload" field.

BREAKING CHANGE: event data for TermRequest and TermResponse is now a table

---

This enables plugins to do things like add signs to terminal buffers to indicate shell prompts. Demo:

[Screencast from 2024-12-17 10-44-18.webm](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/120059fc-6d47-4349-8b93-2d019de95e14)

comment_data.body:
This doesn't completely work. In some cases, vterm seems to call the `on_osc` callback before it's updated its cursor position, so it reports the wrong position. This seems to happen more frequently when there is a lot of text (e.g. `ls -al` vs just `ls`).

**EDIT:** Ah no, it happens when text enters into the scrollback. So could be a scrollback bug (fun...)

Typically `:help v:event` should not need to enumerate every event for a field; rather the field should describe is general purpose, then each help doc for each event mentions the `v:event` fields that it sets.

IOW: `:help TermRequest` should mention these v:event fields. 

Also, `:help TermRequest` already mentions `:help event-data` but I see that it sets `args.data` to a string. I think in general we shouldn't be shy about adding more fields to `args` (and those fields should ideally match `v:event` where possible). E.g. `args.row`, `args.col`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -63,8 +63,10 @@ error('Cannot require a meta file')
 --- complete item selected.
 --- @field height? integer
 --- @field width? integer Height of popup menu on |CompleteChanged|
---- @field row? integer Width of popup menu on |CompleteChanged|
---- Col count of popup menu on |CompleteChanged|, relative to screen.
+--- @field row? integer For |CompleteChanged|: width of popup menu. For |TermRequest|: current
+--- cursor row when escape sequence was received.
+--- For |CompleteChanged|: col count of popup menu, relative to screen. For |TermRequest|: current
+--- cursor column when escape sequence was received.

comment_data.body:
`args.data` has been the place where we put arbitrary event data, reserving the top level table for well-known (and documented) fields like "buf", "file", etc. If we start putting arbitrary data in the top-level then it (1) risks conflicts with the well-known fields (users can add arbitrary data with `nvim_exec_autocmds`), and (2) makes the `data` sub-field meaningless (or, at best, confusing).

I don't think we should add new event data to the top-level field, but we could consider making a breaking change to the TermRequest autocommand to make `args.data` a table instead. Then we would have `args.data.payload` for the actual escape sequence, and `args.data.row` and `args.data.col`.

SGTM

comment_data.body: `ev.data.data` is probably the right name, though it's a bit redundant I guess. Not a blocker.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -144,8 +144,8 @@ directory indicated in the request. >lua
   vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd({ 'TermRequest' }, {
     desc = 'Handles OSC 7 dir change requests',
     callback = function(ev)
-      if string.sub(vim.v.termrequest, 1, 4) == '\x1b]7;' then
-        local dir = string.gsub(vim.v.termrequest, '\x1b]7;file://[^/]*', '')
+      if string.sub(ev.data.payload, 1, 4) == '\x1b]7;' then
+        local dir = string.gsub(ev.data.payload, '\x1b]7;file://[^/]*', '')

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
				- payload: the received sequence
				- row: cursor row
				- col: cursor column
```

 TermResponse			When Nvim receives an OSC or DCS response from

-				|event-data| is the response string. May be

-				a shell command, or anything else that takes
-				time). Example: >lua
+				|event-data| is a table with the following fields:
+
+				  payload: the received sequence

title: feat(terminal)!: include cursor position in TermRequest event data
